lines.text:
[there is a knock on the door]
The door's open.
Sam... , Getting to be a big man, Sam.
I own some land.
...with a fence around it.
That's right.
There are getting to be too many fences for me, Sam. My business depends on open range.
Well then maybe you ought to change your business, Clay.
No, Sam. I don't see it that way. 'Way I see it, as soon as this National Cattle Trail Bill passes, my business'll just be starting.
I don't expect it to pass. I'm doing everything I can to stop it.
Well, kinda puts us on different sides of that fence I was talking about, don't it?
You can say that.
Sam, I don't want to fight with you. I think a lot of you. You remember that first day you come to work for me down the brush country?
I remember it.
Just back from the war... your land. gone... your folks dead. You were some green, boy but you learned fast.
You trying to say something, Clay?
I figure you might still learn fast. I'm offering you a chance to put in with me, Sam.
I figure you know the answer.
You're being a fool, boy.
It's possible.
Sam, we're friends. I taught you a lot about the cow business. You think I'd go into this if I didn't know what I was doing? I got a million dollars in back of me.
You have a lot of cattle in Texas, Clay. Wyoming is the last spot on Earth you have to sow 'em. You're a man between a rock and a hard place looking for a way out.
Alright, Sam. S'pose what you say is true, I'll still make a million dollars. Any reason why you shouldn't be a part of it?
Yeah, plenty of reason, Clay but I doubt you'd understand it
